content.text: A map is a scale drawing of the place it represents. You can use a map to find actual distances to any place in the world. How can you estimate the distance from Cape Town, South Africa to Port Elizabeth, South Africa?
Suppose that you want to find the width of a river that is too wide to measure directly. How can you use similar triangles to find the distance across the river?
Here is a picture of Duke, a real dog. If you know the scale factor between Duke and the picture, how can you determine how long Duke is from his nose to the tip of his tail?

You probably use the word similar in everyday conversation. For example, you might say that one song sounds similar to another song. You may also say that your friend’s bike is similar to yours. In many cases, you might use the word similar to describe objects and images that are the same shape but not the same size.

A floor plan of a house has the same shape as the actual house, but it is much smaller. The images on a movie screen as the same shape as the real people and objects they depict, but they are much larger. You can order your school portrait in a variety of sizes, but your face will have the same shape in each photo. In the Shapes and Design units you studied a variety of shapes, including the properties that make some shapes important in science, engineering, construction, and art.
What features of shapes are important in determining the unique shape, like polygons?
When you encounter a new problem, it is a good idea to ask yourself questions. In this Unit, you might ask questions such as:
What determines whether two shapes are similar?
What is the same and what is different about two similar figures?
When figures are similar, how are the side lengths, areas, and scale factors related?
How can I use similar figures to find missing measurements?

In this Investigation, you will make scale drawings of figures called similar figures. Your scale drawings will have the same shape as the original figure but may be larger or smaller. The drawings will help you explore how some properties of a shape change when the shape is enlarged or reduced.

The Mystery Club at P.I. Middle School meets monthly. Members watch videos, discuss novels, play “whodunit” games, and talk about real-life mysteries. One day, a member announces that the school is having a contest. A teacher in disguise will appear for a few minutes at school each day for a week. Any student can pay $1 for a guess at the identity of the mystery teacher. The student with the first correct guess wins a prize.
The Mystery Club decides to enter the contest together. Each member brings a camera to school in hopes of getting a picture of the mystery teacher.

One of Daphne’s photos looks like the picture below. Daphne has a copy of the P.I. Monthly magazine shown in the picture. The P.I. Monthly magazine is 10 inches high. She thinks the photo might be helpful in determining the height of the mystery teacher.
• Is Daphne's claim correct? Is it possible to use the magazine and the picture to estimate the teacher's height? Explain.
• Could you find the height of the teacher if you did not know that the magazine was 10 inches tall? Explain.

Situation A. Daphne’s Reasoning Daphne claims she used proportional reasoning to solve the problem. She wrote:Each PI magazine measures 10 inches in real life. I used the PI magazine height to measure the height of the teacher. Complete Daphne’s reasoning to estimate the height of the teacher.
Situation B. What’s Different? How does the real-life teacher differ from the teacher in the photo?
Situation C. Can you think of some other times you could use a photo to estimate the size of something?
The Mystery Club advisor says that the picture is similar to the actual scene. What do you suppose the advisor means by similar? How is the photo similar to the actual scene that is photographed?

In Problem 1.1 A, Daphne used proportional reasoning to solve the mystery. She reasoned: Each PI magazine height measures 10 inches in real life. I used the PI magazine height to measure the height of the teacher. The teacher is 7 PI magazines tall. So, in real life the teacher is 7 x 10 inches or 70 inches tall. Daphne’s reasoning is similar to the reasoning you have done in the Comparing Quantities unit where you used ratios to describe and compare quantities. Recall that a ratio is a comparison of two quantities, such as two lengths. 1 PI magazine height to the height of the teacher (7 PI magazines) or 1 PI magazine: 7 PI magazines or 10 in: 70 in

content.text: In the last Problem, you worked with images, or scale drawings, that were similar to the original. Those scale drawings were larger than the original figure. In this Problem, you will work with scale drawings that are smaller than the original. You will also learn more about what it means for figures to be similar.

When you study similar figures, you often compare their sides and angles. To compare the parts correctly, mathematicians use the terms corresponding sides and corresponding angles. In every pair of similar figures, each side of one figure has a corresponding side in the other figure. Also, each angle has a corresponding angle. Recall that there are two ways to identify angles.
You can identify an angle with three letters. The angles in the small triangle have the following names:
Angle BAC or ∠BAC
Angle BCA or ∠BCA
Angle ABC or ∠ABC
Notice that the letter identifying the vertex of an angle is always the middle letter in its name. For example, point A is the vertex of ∠BAC.
You can also name an angle by its vertex. It is important to use this method only when it is clear which angle you are referring to.
∠BAC can also be called ∠ A
∠BCA can also be called ∠ C
∠ABC can also be called ∠ B
What names would you give the angles in the large triangle above?
Name the corresponding angles in the following two similar triangles?

Zack and Marta want to design a computer game that involves several animated characters. They ask Marta’s uncle, Carlos, a programmer for a video game company, about computer animation.

Carlos explains that the computer screen can be thought of as a grid made up of thousands of tiny points, called pixels. To animate a figure, you need to enter the coordinates of key points on the figure. The computer uses these points to draw the figure in different positions. Sometimes the figures in a computer game need to change size. A change in the code can make a figure larger or smaller. You can give it a rule for finding key points from the original figure. Do the rules create scale drawings? That is, are the two figures similar?

Zack and Marta’s computer game involves a family called the Wumps. The members of the Wump family are various sizes, but they all have the same shape. They are similar. Mug Wump is the game’s main character. By enlarging or reducing Mug, a player can transform him into other Wump family members.

Zack and Marta experiment with enlarging and reducing figures on a coordinate grid. First, Zack draws Mug Wump on graph paper. Then he labels the key points from A to X and lists the coordinates for each point. Marta writes the rules that will change Mug’s size. Marta tries several rules for transforming Mug into different sizes. She wonders which rules will make family members that are similar shapes.

Use the coordinate rules in the table to draw Mug, Zug, Lug, Bug, and Glug on coordinate graph paper.
Mug Wump: (x, y), Zug: (2x, 2y), Lug: (3x, y), Bug: (3x, 3y), Glug: (x, 3y)

• Use the given rule to find the coordinates of the points. Record the coordinates in Tables for Zug, Lug, Bug, and Glug. For example, the rule for Zug is (2x, 2y). This means that you multiply each of Mug’s coordinates by 2. Point A on Mug is (0, 1), so the corresponding point A on Zug is (0, 2). Point B on Mug is (2, 1), so the corresponding point B on Zug is (4, 2).

• Look at the figures created by Marta’s rules. Which ones appear to be family members who are similar to Mug? Which figures appear not to be similar, and thus “imposters”? How do you know?

content.text: In the computer game the characters were members of the Wump family. You found a way to decide which characters were imposters using the coordinate rule.
How can you decide whether two shapes are similar?

You have experimented with rubber-band stretchers, copiers, and coordinate plots. Your experiments suggest that for two figures to be similar, there must be the following correspondence between the figures:
  • Corresponding angles are the same size
  • The side lengths of one figure are multiplied by the same number to get the corresponding side lengths in the second figure.

The scale factor is the number that the side lengths of one figure can be multiplied by to give the corresponding side lengths of a similar figure.
  • What is the multiplier or scale factor when you use two rubber bands to enlarge a figure?
  • What is the multiplier or scale factor when you use a copier setting of 150%? 75%?

The rectangles below are similar. The scale factor from the smaller rectangle to the larger rectangle is 3. That is, for every 1 cm in the original figure, there are 3 cm in the image.  The ratio of the original length of a side to the length of a corresponding side is 1:3.
What is the scale factor from the larger rectangle to the smaller rectangle? Explain how you found it.

problems.title: 3.1 Rep-Tile Quadrilaterals
problems.subtitle: Forming Rep-Tiles with Similar Quadrilaterals and Triangles

content.text: In Shapes and Designs, you learned that some polygons fit together to cover, or tile, a flat surface. For example, the surface of a honeycomb has a pattern of regular hexagons. Many bathroom and kitchen floors are covered with a pattern of square tiles. These patterns of polygons that fit together are called tessellations.

Look closely at the pattern of squares. You can see that the large square consists of nine small squares. The large square is similar to each of the nine small squares. The large square has sides formed by the sides of three small squares, so the scale factor from the small square to the large square is 3.

You can also put four small squares together to make a four-tile square. This four-tile square is similar to both the large nine-tile square and the small single-tile square. The scale factor from the single-tile square to the four-tile square is 2. The scale factor from the four-tile square to the single-tile square is 1/2.
No matter how closely you look at the hexagon pattern, however, you cannot find a large hexagon made up of similar smaller hexagons.

A shape is a rep-tile if you can put together congruent (same size and shape) copies of the shape to make a larger, similar shape. The congruent copies may be rotated in order to fit together. A square is a rep-tile, but a regular hexagon is not.

In the Comparing Bits and Pieces unit, you used ratios to describe and compare quantities. A ratio is a comparison of two quantities, such as two lengths. The rectangle around the original figure is about 10 centimeters tall and 8 centimeters wide. You can say, “The ratio of height to width is 10 to 8.
This table gives the ratios of height to width for the images.

What do you notice about the height-to-width ratios? The comparisons “10 to 8” and “5 to 4” are equivalent ratios. Equivalent ratios are like equivalent fractions. In fact, ratios are often written in fraction form. You can express equivalent ratios with equations. A proportion is an equation stating that two ratios are equal.
